;朝鲜官方媒体周五谴责美国航母抵达韩国，称其为军事挑衅，可能带来“不可挽回的灾难性局面”。

;

;核动力航空母舰罗纳德·里根号及其打击群;抵达; 周四在韩国釜山港进行为期五天的访问，参加盟军演习，以向朝鲜展示武力。

;

;朝鲜官方朝中社表示，这架航空公司的访问表明，美国对其国家进行核攻击的计划已达到“最严重阶段”，这意味着“核战争即将爆发”。

;

;“这是赤裸裸的军事挑衅，推动着朝中社在评论中表示，“将局势演变成不可挽回的灾难性情况”。

;

;美国和韩国军队今年一直在进行一系列强化的军事演习，其中包括;美国航空母舰;、;潜艇;和尖端轰炸机，以更好地应对不断变化的朝鲜核威胁和导弹威胁。朝鲜称这些演习是入侵的预演。

;

;如果发生迫在眉睫的核攻击，平壤将采取其核学说中规定的“必要行动”，并承诺“彻底威慑和击退美国及其傀儡” ' 发动核战争的疯狂举动，”它说。

;

;我们的“最有力、最迅速的第一打击将是美国用来迷惑其追随者的‘延伸威慑’手段，以及朝鲜半岛及其周边地区的邪恶基地，”朝中社称。

;

;以色列军事首长表示，“现在是战争的时候了”，正如他的国家;在计划进行地面入侵以消灭巴勒斯坦武装分子之前，在加沙地带附近集结了坦克;统治该飞地的哈马斯组织。

;

;为了为其应对措施赢得支持，以色列政府向美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯和北约国防部长展示了;儿童和平民的图形图像;，他们说哈马斯在以色列周末的暴乱中被杀。

;

;布林肯说他们展示了< a href="/world/middle-east/blinken-says-israeli-government-shared-images-hamas-atrocities-2023-10-12/">;婴儿“浑身是弹”，;士兵被斩首年轻人在车里被烧伤。 “这简直是最糟糕的堕落，”他说。 “这真的超出了我们所能理解的范围。”

;

;以色列发誓要对这次袭击进行报复，这是以色列历史上巴勒斯坦武装分子发动的最致命的一次袭击。

;

;与全球其他地方的其他人一样，布林肯敦促以色列保持克制，但他也;重申美国的支持;，并表示：“我们将永远在你身边。”

;

;周五，作为中东之行的一部分，他将在约旦会见阿卜杜拉国王和以色列占领的约旦河西岸巴勒斯坦权力机构负责人马哈茂德·阿巴斯旨在阻止战争的溢出效应。

;

;美国最高外交官布林肯计划访问美国的主要盟友卡塔尔、沙特阿拉伯、埃及和阿拉伯联合酋长国，其中一些国家对伊朗支持的伊斯兰组织哈马斯有影响力.

;

;以色列军事参谋长赫尔齐·哈勒维中将表示，将从加沙周围导致此次袭击的安全失败中吸取教训。他说：“我们将学习、调查，但现在是战争的时候了。”

;

;;美国国防部长劳埃德·奥斯汀表示，美国军方对以色列的安全援助不设任何条件;，并补充说华盛顿希望以色列军队在对以色列发动战争时“做正确的事”哈马斯。

;

;奥斯汀将于周五抵达以色列，并计划会见以色列总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡。

;

;哈马斯呼吁巴勒斯坦人周五起来;抗议以色列轰炸飞地;，敦促巴勒斯坦人向东耶路撒冷耶路撒冷进军阿克萨清真寺以及在被占领的约旦河西岸与以色列军队发生冲突。

;

;以色列议会批准了;内塔尼亚胡的紧急团结政府;于周四晚间召开，其中包括一些中间派反对派议员，以展示该国打击哈马斯的团结决心。

;

;公共广播公司菅直人称以色列死亡人数已增至1300余人。数十名以色列和外国人质被带回加沙；以色列表示已确认其中 97 人的身份。

;

;迄今为止，以色列的应对措施是对拥有 230 万人口的加沙进行围困，并发起轰炸行动，摧毁了整个社区。加沙当局表示，已有 1,500 多名巴勒斯坦人被杀。

;

;红十字国际委员会 (ICRC) 表示，加沙医院的应急发电机燃料可能会在数小时内耗尽，联合国世界粮食计划署 ​​(粮食计划署警告说，粮食和淡水已经严重短缺。

;

;红十字国际委员会地区主任法布里奇奥·卡尔博尼 (Fabrizio Carboni) 表示：“局势升级造成的人类苦难令人深恶痛绝，我恳求双方减少平民的痛苦。”

;

;国际刑事法院表示，它已;对哈马斯和以色列在加沙地带犯下的潜在战争罪行拥有管辖权。

;

;华盛顿称伊朗;短期内无法访问;上次存放在卡塔尔银行的 60 亿美元伊朗资金一个月作为囚犯交换的一部分。伊朗庆祝了这次袭击，但否认直接参与其中。

;

;这场冲突在欧洲引发了一些内乱，巴黎有警察;使用催泪瓦斯和高压水枪驱散支持巴勒斯坦人民的被禁止集会;。阿姆斯特丹和伦敦的一些犹太学校;出于安全考虑暂时关闭;。< /p>;

;纽约和洛杉矶的美国执法官员表示，他们周五加强了警力部署，特别是在犹太教堂和犹太社区中心周围，但一些官员试图淡化威胁。

;< p>;纽约州州长凯西·霍赫尔 (Kathy Hochul) 表示，家长应该做出“个人选择”，是让孩子离开宗教学校，还是周五晚上不去犹太教堂，以响应亲巴勒斯坦抗议的号召。

;

;《阿拉伯人》阿拉伯倡导组织美国反歧视委员会周四表示，联邦调查局特工走访了不同州的清真寺和有巴勒斯坦血统的美国居民，称这是“令人不安的趋势”。在耶路撒冷，数十名以色列人周四聚集在赫茨尔山军事公墓埋葬死者。

;

;“当你没有接我的电话时，我知道你正在全力战斗。当我意识到时你失踪了，我无法想象事情会这样结束。”一位哀悼者说道。

;

;在加沙南部主要城市;Khan Younis;，那里的墓地已经满了，死者被埋在空地上，就像周三晚上在一场谋杀案中被杀的萨穆尔家族一样。袭击击中了他们的房屋。

;

;巴勒斯坦救援人员易卜拉欣·哈姆丹 (Ibrahim Hamdan) 开车从一个炸弹地点前往另一个炸弹地点，他的团队试图从被以色列空袭摧毁的房屋中救出幸存者。

;

;“这战争的残酷程度超乎想象。他们在没有任何警告的情况下推倒人们的建筑物。他们把高层建筑推倒在居民身上。”哈姆丹说，他自 2007 年成为救援人员以来，多次经历过战争。

;

;加沙人主要是 1948 年以色列建国时逃离或被驱逐出家园的难民的后裔，自 16 年前哈马斯夺取政权以来，他们遭受了经济崩溃和以色列在封锁下的多次轰炸。

;

;巴勒斯坦人近几个月来，以色列在约旦河西岸进行了多年来最致命的镇压，其右翼政府谈论要夺取更多土地，愤怒情绪不断高涨。旨在建立巴勒斯坦国的和平进程十年前崩溃了，巴勒斯坦领导人表示，这让人民没有希望，极端主义势力不断壮大。

;;在这张 2 月 21 日拍摄的插图中，美国前总统唐纳德·特朗普的显示屏前的智能手机上可以看到真相社交网络徽标，2022 年。REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo;
;

;Digital World Acquisition Corp ;(DWAC.O); 是一家计划与美国前总统唐纳德·特朗普的媒体和科技公司合并的 SPAC，该公司本周表示，将向投资者返还为此次交易筹集的 5.33 亿美元。已经收回了 4.67 亿美元的承诺。

;

;这一进展意味着所谓的私募股权投资 (PIPE) 交易的结束，该交易本可以让运营商特朗普媒体科技集团 (TMTG) 获得成功特朗普的 Truth Social 平台的 10 亿美元，作为其与 Digital World 合并的一部分。

;

;SPAC（特殊目的收购公司）或空白支票公司是一家公开上市的空壳公司，负责筹集资金进行合并

;

;Digital World 去年筹集了 10 亿美元的 PIPE，但未能在 2022 年 9 月的最后期限前完成与 TMTG 的合并，因为美国金融监管机构因 Digital World 向投资者披露信息而搁置了该交易。这使得 PIPE 投资者有权取消其承诺。

;

;TMTG 首席执行官 Devin Nunes 在一份新闻稿中表示，终止 PIPE“符合 TMTG 股东的最佳利益，并尽快完成与 DWAC 的合并” TMTG 发言人在周四的一份声明中表示，终止 PIPE 是“完成我们合并的关键一步”。她没有回答为什么在合并之前终止 PIPE 对 TMTG 有利的问题。

;

;8 月 9 日，TMTG 与 Digital World 的交易修正案要求解除 PIPE。这项修正案赋予特朗普在 Digital World 中拥有更多投票权的新股。

;

;PIPE 的解除将使 Digital World 获得其在 2021 年 9 月首次公开募股中筹集的 2.93 亿美元现金，该现金设定为交易完成后前往 TMTG。如果投资者选择赎回，这笔资金也可能会缩水。

;

;TMTG 发言人没有回答有关该公司是否计划筹集额外资金的问题。据路透社去年 10 月报道，TMTG 此前从私人投资者那里筹集了 2280 万美元的资金。

;

;Digital World 和 TMTG 调整了合并协议，以便任何一方都可以在 10 月 31 日至 11 月 21 日之间终止交易，如果他们的董事会不再相信合并会给股东带来好处。根据 2021 年 2 月 2 日的服务协议，特朗普控制 TMTG 90% 的股份。

;

;自 2021 年 10 月与 TMTG 达成协议以来，Digital World 面临着多项挑战。该公司已成为美国司法部和证券交易委员会的调查对象，罢免了首席执行官，并改组了董事会。

;

;9 月，Digital World 投资者投票决定延长其任期。 TMTG 交易最多需要一年的时间才能完成，而该交易的最后期限已被多次推迟。目前尚不清楚 Digital World 何时以及是否会要求股东就与 TMTG 的交易进行投票，这是完成交易的必要步骤。

;

;Digital World 的股价周四下跌 2%，至 15.54 美元，远低于峰值2022 年 3 月每股价格约为 97 美元。

;;美国参议员鲍勃·梅嫩德斯（新泽西州民主党）在国会山参议院民主党核心小组会议结束后前往投票途中向记者发表讲话美国华盛顿，2023 年 9 月 28 日。路透社/Craig Hudson/档案照片;
;

;

;

;埃里森;说周三，她流着泪;表示，她生活在“恐惧”之中，真相会大白，去年 FTX 的最终崩溃给她带来了“压倒性的解脱感”。

;

;Australians will be asked to vote in a ;referendum on Oct. 14; to constitutionally recognise its Indigenous people through the establishment of a representative body that can provide non-binding advice to the parliament.

;

;Here's what you need to know about Australia's Voice to Parliament campaign:

;

;Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are the Indigenous people of Australia.

;

;They represent about 3.8% of its population.超过 800,000 名原住民及其祖先在这片土地上居住了至少 60,000 年。 They comprise several hundred groups that have their own histories, traditions and languages.

;

;Australia's Indigenous population plummeted after British colonisation began in 1788 as they were dispossessed of their land, exposed to new diseases, forced to work in slave-like conditions, and killed by colonisers.

;

;The marginalisation of Australia's First Nations people has continued until recent years.

;

;Aboriginal people track below national averages on most socio-economic measures and suffer disproportionately high rates of suicide, domestic violence and imprisonment. Their life expectancy is about eight years lower than non-Indigenous people.

;

;One in three Indigenous children were forcibly removed from their families over 1910 to the 1970s in a bid to assimilate them into white society. The government apologised for the so-called 'Stolen Generation' in 2008.

;

;First Nations people in other former British colonies continue to face marginalisation, but some countries have done better in ensuring their rights.

;

;Canada recognises the rights of its Indigenous people under the Constitution Act 1982.

;

;New Zealand's 1840 Treaty of Waitangi promises to protect Maori culture. The country also created Maori seats in parliament, allowing the Indigenous population to choose to vote for candidates for these seats or participate in the general election.

;

;Te reo Maori has been recognised as an official language and is used in schools, universities and public offices.

;

;Indigenous people began to be included in Australia's census figures after a referendum to amend the constitution in 1967, more than 60 years after it was established as a nation in 1901.

;

;In 2017, about 250 First Nations representatives gathered at the sacred monolith landmark of Uluru in central Australia and produced the Uluru Statement from the Heart, which calls for a First Nations Voice enshrined in the Constitution.

;

;The conservative government at the time rejected the call.

;

;In 2022, Labor's Anthony Albanese became prime minister and said Australians would have their say in a referendum to include an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice to Parliament.

;

;The ;latest opinion polls; this month showed more Australians are planning to vote no in the referendum than yes.

;

;The referendum is one of Albanese's key issues and he has staked much of his political capital on it.

;

;Albanese's Labor Party, the left-wing Greens party, some independent lawmakers, several welfare groups, national religious and ethno-religious groups all support the referendum.

;

;But there are those who oppose it on both sides of the political divide.

;

;Independent Indigenous senator Lidia Thorpe quit the Green party over concerns about the Voice proposal. She wants a treaty between the government and Indigenous people first, similar to what exists in New Zealand and Canada.

;

;The conservative Liberal Party and the rural-based National Party are against the proposal and are asking Australians to vote "No" in the referendum. The Liberals and the Nationals have a long-standing coalition agreement.

;

;A "No" campaign, or "Recognise a Better Way" campaign, has proposed to set up an all-party parliamentary committee to focus on the rights of native title holders instead of establishing a Voice to Parliament through a referendum.

;The US on Thursday imposed the first sanctions on owners of tankers carrying Russian oil priced above the G7's price cap of $60 a barrel, one in Turkey and one in the United Arab Emirates, in an effort to close loopholes in the mechanism designed to punish Moscow for its war in Ukraine.

;

;The US, other G7 countries and Australia imposed the cap last year, seeking to reduce Russia's revenues from seaborne oil exports as part of sanctions for its invasion of Ukraine.

;

;The cap bans Western companies from providing maritime services, including insurance, finance and shipping, for Russian seaborne oil exports sold above $60 a barrel, while seeking to keep oil flowing to markets. Caps also were imposed on Russian fuel exports.

;

;US President Joe Biden's administration placed sanctions on Turkey-based Ice Pearl Navigation SA, owner of the Yasa Golden Bosphorus, which the Treasury said carried Russian ESPO crude priced above $80 a barrel after the cap took effect in December last year.

;

;The US also imposed them on UAE-based Lumber Marine SA, owner of the SCF Primorye, which the Treasury said was carrying Novy Port Russian crude above $75 per barrel.

;

;"Because of the actions we're announcing today, and the further actions we will take in the coming weeks and months, these costs will continue to rise and Russia's ability to sustain its barbaric war will continue to weaken," a senior Treasury official, speaking on condition of anonymity, told reporters in a call.

;

;The measures identify and block access to all property and interests owned by the companies in the US

;

;The price cap coalition also ;issued; recommendations for the maritime industry including: a requirement for "appropriately capitalized" protection and indemnity insurance, agreed protocols on the use of Automatic Identification Systems and enhanced checks of high-risk ship-to-ship cargo transfers.

;

;Both tankers, which conducted port calls in Russia, used US-based service providers while transporting the Russian origin oil, the Treasury said without answering questions about those providers.

;

;The US service providers would not be at risk of sanctions if they had been provided false or misleading information by others in the shipping chain about the price of Russian oil, said a price cap coalition official on condition of anonymity.

;

;Turkey's Yasa Holding, operator of the Golden Bosphorus, said it had necessary documentation from major London insurers for it to carry Russian origin cargoes and that it has been company policy for more than a year to not carry Russian crude.

;

;Yasa said the vessel is currently under time-charter for three to five months with Exxon Mobil ;(XOM.N);.

;

;The US oil major said it does not trade Russian oil or oil products. "These deliveries are certified products of Canadian origin," Exxon said about the chartering.

;

;A price cap coalition official speaking on condition of anonymity said Exxon was not a target of the sanctions and that the company had chartered the vessel after it had carried Russian oil.

;

;Global oil prices have risen to around $85 a barrel in recent months on production cuts and thin world spare production capacity. That has helped to limit the efficacy of the cap, but the coalition can toughen enforcement to make it more effective, according to people who advised the Treasury.

;

;Russian crude oil exports last month stood at 4.9 million barrels per day, down about 100,000 bpd from the May-June average, the International Energy Agency (IEA) estimated on Thursday. But it also said Russia's total exports of crude oil and products in September rose by 460,000 bpd to 7.6 million bpd, with crude accounting for 250,000 bpd of the increase.

;

;The cap has forced Russia and traders to invest in what the industry refers to as a ghost fleet of old tankers vulnerable to leaks and oil spills. Those vessels are undertaking long voyages to deliver crude to refiners in China and India, which have become the largest buyers of Russian crude. Neither country has imposed sanctions on trade with Russia.

;

;The cap forces Russia to pay about $36 a barrel for those non-Western maritime services, expenses that go to "tankers not tanks" in the Ukraine war, the US Treasury official said.

;

;Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen on Wednesday said the price cap had ;sharply reduced; Russian revenues over the past 10 months, and that it was critical to keep imposing severe and increasing costs on Russia.

;

;Andriy Yermak, the head of Ukraine's presidential office, said on the Telegram messaging app the sanctions resulted from studies by an international working group he helped create and that violations of the Russian oil price cap will be punished.
